title: Trump Names His New NSA Adviser
text:
President Donald Trump announced on Monday that Army Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster will be his next national security adviser.
McMaster will replace Lt. Gen. (Ret.) Michael Flynn, whose resignation Trump asked for following his failure to accurately communicate with Vice President Pence the content of conversations he had with the Russian ambassador.
Trump made the announcement at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., with Gen. McMaster and acting NSA adviser Lt. Gen. Keith Kellogg seated on either side of him.

H. R. McMaster will take over the role of national security adviser after Gen. Michael Flynn resigned. pic.twitter.com/Zga0nVeCwq 
— Fox News (@FoxNews) February 20, 2017 

“He’s a man of tremendous talent and tremendous experience,” the president said of McMaster. 
The general is a 1984 graduate of West Point and earned his master’s and Ph.D. in history from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

He is a veteran of the Gulf and Iraq wars, as well as Operation Enduring Freedom in Afghanistan.
McMaster also served in multiple roles at U.S Central Command.
The general published a book in 1997 entitled, Dereliction of Duty: Lyndon Johnson, Robert McNamara, The Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the Lies that Led to Vietnam . The work was based on his doctoral thesis at UNC.

At the time, it was believed to be based on the officer’s willingness to challenge the status quo , which would certainly align with Trump’s election mandate.
The NSA adviser is part of the president’s White House staff, and therefore does not require senate approval.
Trump announced that Kellogg will be staying on at the NSC as chief of staff to McMaster. “That combination is something very, very special,” the president said. 
Trump also stated that former U.N. Ambassador John Bolton, who the president considered for the NSA adviser role, will be working with his administration in a different capacity.
“He has a good number of ideas that I agree very much with,” said Trump.
